Title: $AB-BA=I$ having no solutions
Content: The following question is from Artin's Algebra . If $A$ and $B$ are two square matrices with real entries, show that $AB-BA=I$ has no solutions. I have no idea on how to tackle this question. I tried block multiplication, but it didn't appear to work.
AcceptedAnswer: As you should have known by now, for real matrices, the equation $AB-BA=I$ has no solution because the LHS has zero trace but the RHS is not traceless. The same conclusion holds for complex matrices. For other fields, an in-depth discussion can be found in the answers to a related question . In particular , it has been proven that a square matrix $M$ is a commutator (i.e. $M=AB-BA$ for some square matrices $A$ and $B$ ) if and only if $M$ is traceless: A.A. Albert and Benjamin Muckenhoupt (1957), " On matrices of trace zeros ". Michigan Math. J. , 4(1):1-3. It follows that $AB-BA=I_n$ has a solution if and only if $I_n$ is traceless over the underlying field.
